entry.title: La Gente Newsmagazine Fall Issue '22
entry.summary: For this project, I contributed as both the Visuals Editor and Layout…
entry.content:
For this project, I contributed as both the Visuals Editor and Layout Editor, with my primary focus being the overall appearance of this quarter's theme. I contributed visuals myself such as the cover image, as well as making, editing, and overseeing the process of creating the overall magazine layout of our digital spring issue. In addition, I worked with the visual team to edit and provide feedback on their pieces to encourage growth and a healthy learning environment. 

Click through this issue below.

entry.title: BruinPlanner
entry.summary: In a team of five, we interviewed five participants who were all…
entry.content:
In a team of five, we interviewed five participants who were all UCLA students taking Fundamentals of User Experience to gain further insight to the usability of our product, Bruin Planner. For this portion of the project, we tested the flow of changing a course from a generated plan for the Winter 2021 term. To test this, we conducted a usability test, designing a prototype on Figma in which the interviewee was asked to complete the task by clicking through the prototype and navigating through a series of slides demonstrating BruinPlanner’s interface. This testing activity needed to be conducted in order to gain knowledge of a user’s understanding and interaction with the app to assess whether its state meets user’s expectations and goals.

Conducting these interviews, we found that many interviewees used prior knowledge of class planners to navigate through BruinPlanner, hoping that the process in changing courses were more abridged and required less steps, and the amount of detailed information on a course should vary depending on the task. Based on this new insight, the development team can implement new design changes to reflect the user’s input such as minimizing the app’s interface by removing clutter and unnecessary screen confirmations to create a more streamlined process in changing their plans. In addition, the team can reflect further on our research questions that focus on four-year degree planning and explore further how it can be balanced to match user’s previous expectations in quarter-to-quarter class planning to create a more intuitive and easy experience.

Over the course of this project, we learned how to conduct a productive user interview to gain intel on current student’s needs and goals, design and present a prototype, and interpret usability test reports to further develop BruinPlanner. Since the first research activity, we have updated our requirements list to include displaying only the title of the course and an option to expand and view more information, and keeping the process of customizing courses limited to 2-3 steps with no repetition or redundancy. In addition, new changes made to the root cause analysis reflect more accurately the user's ultimate goals in having a fun, engaging college experience. 

Along with another group member, we created low and high-fidelity wireframes for the app and making the prototype. 

Low-Fidelity Wireframes

High-Fidelity Wireframes

Prototype

Interact with our application below!

entry.title: Gender and Development
entry.summary: About For the Fall Quarter '21 course Introduction to Digital Humanities, I…
entry.content:
About 

For the Fall Quarter '21 course Introduction to Digital Humanities, I collaborated with four other students to create a website from scratch that would be the platform for our findings while analyzing our selected dataset. 
 
For our data, we picked a dataset from the OECD’s The Gender, Institutions and Development Database from 2019, specifically examining the differences and similarities of Eastern European countries when it came to gender attitudes, such as when it comes to violence against women and political voice. 
 
I was the primary website designer, meaning I foresaw the entirety of the design process from selecting themes, selecting a color scheme, and editing the website content using Wordpress hosted by Humspace. 

View our team's website here!

entry.title: PrEP Accessibility at UCLA
entry.summary: About After identifying a crucial concern of sexual health safety within the…
entry.content:
About

After identifying a crucial concern of sexual health safety within the queer community, particularly in relation to HIV and college campuses, we moved forward with our website to introduce a platform that empowers queer undergraduate UCLA students by creating a space for open, honest discussion of the struggles to obtain Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis, the HIV-preventative medication otherwise known as PrEP. Our website focuses on showcasing why people take PrEP, the struggles to obtain or learn about PrEP, and thereby see whether the existing sexual health infrastructure regarding PrEP at UCLA satisfies the queer undergrraduate community. 

For this project, I was in charge of the web design. I worked closely with the back-end developer to create a layout of the website that not only is intuitive, but communicative and enfocuses on the user's stories. I first started with making wireframes for our group website, focusing mainly on including the requirements for our class, but also a way to highlight and centralize our user stories in a way that was not too overwhelming and user-friendly. We wanted to display answers to our Google Survey using GIS, JavaScript, and HTML/CSS that will be user-friendly, highlight the importance and voices of these community members, and lead us to our main goal which is to be descriptive, rather than prescriptive, allies towards this community. 

First Version

 

While our first version included what was required, it was missing the most vital thing which was a clear and easy-to-follow narrative for our mission with this project. To emphasize this, we revisited our flow chart to hone in on the narrative we are trying to vocalize, and revisioned our prototypes. 

In addition to revising our flow chart, we met up multiple times and discussed heavily with our instructor, Albert, who worked through the process and really gave us the foundation to move forward with our vision. During these discussions, I made wireframes and diagrams to possible ideas that eventually led us to our final version. 

After several revisions and edits, we finally settled on a layout that we found empowered our user's stories, be accessible and user-friendly.

To view the final result, visit our website here!
